content.description: Scramble up to the ledge, follow the bolts that branch left.
This crack is sort of fun. Could probably go on gear if one really felt like it.
content.protection: Top Rope or small medium gear. Anchor is up over the top.
content.location: To the right of Skytop there is a clean face 50ft up, it has three routes, two cracks and a bolted climb. This is the right most crack.

content.description: This loose gnarly "crack" is waiting to squash unsuspecting bugs. The whole deal is waiting to fall off...
content.location: To the right of Skytop there is  face that begins about 50ft up. It has three climbs, two cracks and a bolted line, this is the left most crack.

content.description: Climb the arete left of the corner, move right, continue the corner

The business is slow to start. The meatiness comes at you right from the ledge. Begin on the right hand (and better quality) corner, below the clean face up high. Move up nice moderate trad moves and some gear to the ledge, look up and get ready. Climb the the center of the face through 4 bolts placed to keep you from the ledge to a two bolt anchor. Avoid the lefthand crack unless you wanna die! There is an old Garvey stud that was part of an old  project right off the ledge.
content.protection: Gear to 1.5 inches, 4 bolts. Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Right of Skytop there is a clean face 50ft up, this is the center (bolted) climb.

content.description: Start in a corner and continue onto the face towards the first bolt.  Awkward gear, but good face holds to finish at the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts, gear to .75", 2 bolt chain anchor

content.description: Bust out the moves for A-tree-ehh and clip the right anchor bolt. From the anchor traverse right to the obvious roof and pull it on good holds and fun moves. Bring slings or long draws to eliminate rope drag. Expect some loose chips until this route sees more traffic.
Climb the short steep crack next to the large spruce tree. Move right at the end of the crack for a two bolt anchor or continue direct for Kids in a Candy Store. Burly start!

This route climbs the clean overhanging groove 3-4 feet right of A-tree-ehh and joins with Roof-oh-lution just below the roof. Steep pinches and liebacks on decent stone will get you to a good rest before the roof. Watch for loose rock before the first bolt. Expect a few loose pebbles until this route sees more traffic. Bring a couple of finger sized pieces for the gap between the third and fourth bolt.
content.location: 4 feet right of A-tree-ehh/Roof-oh-lution and 15 feet left of Calling Out

content.description: Start on a calcite covered bulge and work your way through the tricky overhanging corner. Bring your off width attitude and some small/medium gear for this section, and watch for a bit of loose rock. Pull over the lip for fun face climbing on decent rock. After the last bolt, run it out to the top or bring an optional 3" cam.
content.protection: 5 bolts, gear to 3", two bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This is 10 feet left of Resolution Crack, it is an obvious calcite covered crack/corner.

climbs.name: Kids in a Candy Store
climbs.fa: Chris Williams, Alicia Driscoll, Kelsey Gray, Kyle Arzt

content.description:
Climb Resoultion Crack but skip the first anchor and continue direct. Pull through two steep bulges on good holds and continue direct to the top. Still a few loose chips but good rock overall.  

 A variation of this upper face was climbed by Kelsey Gray and Kyle Arzt on runout and marginal gear. A number of those gear placements were likely pulled off during cleaning.
Same start as Tweakin the Genie, veer to the right.

climbs.name: Cookin the Captain AKA Divine Guidance

content.description: Climb right to a roof and follow the crack in the roof.
content.protection: 5 Bolts, Gear to, very small and medium gear. Without RPs or other microstoppers the crux is pretty scary. This lead is pretty serious.Â

content.description: This is the first climb on the right of Eh-Tree-Ah/Roofolution and just left of Cookin' the Captain. Climb through several bolts to a suspect looking, but super solid crux hold, pull over the lip to very, fun sustained but airy face climbing.  This may be harder than it's original given grade of 5.11b due to hold break.
content.protection: Calling out was equipped with ASCA stainless bolts and hangers. 10 bolts, shares a two bolt ASCA anchor with Captain.

climbs.name: A-Tree-Ehh
climbs.fa: Wes Schaffer, Matt Kline, Grant Walker

content.description: Steep side pulls and crimps. Starts just to the right of the crack and climbs close to the tree. Crap rock to the first bolt then pumpy fun. For more climbing move left from the anchor to Kids in a Candy Store or continue right for Roof-oh-lution.

This route gets sun for much of the day, is relatively free of highway noise and secluded. It has good routes from 5.8 to 5.12. This crag is mostly considered a mixed crag so bring some cams, a single rack from .3 to 2 inches should have you set for most climbs. All of the bolts at resolution are stainless, either wedge anchors on new routes, or ASCA bolts on older routes.
